elements.title: D. M. Clemson (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the freighter D. M. Clemson (pictured) was one of the largest vessels on the Great Lakes in 1903?

elements.title: Miriam Defensor Santiago (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Filipino politician Miriam Defensor Santiago is known as the "Iron Lady of Asia"?

elements.title: a 16th-century ethnic term used in Africa (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that a 16th-century ethnic term used in Africa is still used today for a Brazilian religion, a Togolese and Beninese ethnic group, and their language?

elements.title: Raghunath Brahmbhatt (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that it took 40 years for Raghunath Brahmbhatt to be credited for the lyrics to a popular song he wrote, 21 years after his death?

elements.title: My Family Member (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that My Dad, the first entry in My Family Member, a series of illustrated children books, was inspired by the author's discovery of his father's old gown?

elements.title: John Adams Cameron (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that John Adams Cameron lost twice to John Culpepper in elections for the United States Congress that were 14 years apart?

elements.title: Way of the Warrior (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that neighbors thought Naughty Dog was filming adult films due to their setup of shooting moves for Way of the Warrior from an apartment hallway?

elements.title: Mia Lee (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that painter and designer Mia Lee used to make doll fashions from her grandmother's scraps?

elements.title: Hogan's golf clubs (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Jack Fleck defeated Ben Hogan in a playoff to win the 1955 U.S. Open using Hogan's golf clubs?

elements.title: Destination of the Month (Wikivoyage recommendations)
elements.contents:
Destination of the Month

San Carlos de Bariloche

The Argentine adventure capital offers great opportunities for skiing, sightseeing, water sports, trekking and climbing amidst the amazing mountainous landscapes of Argentine Patagonia.

elements.title: Off the Beaten Path (Wikivoyage recommendations)
elements.contents:
Off the Beaten Path

Sekigahara

This quaint mountain town and battlefield, where Tokugawa won control of Japan, gives visitors firsthand insight into feudal Japanese warfare.

elements.title: Featured Travel Topic (Wikivoyage recommendations)
elements.contents:
Featured Travel Topic

Driving in China

China isn't one of the countries that foreigners commonly explore by driving themselves. If you'd still like to, the first step would be getting a local driving licence.
